candidates.title: Did This Driver Evade Police By Bouncing Off Two Vehicles?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a driver evading police by bouncing the car off the roofs of two vehicles.
Rating:
False
About this rating
Origin
In April 2021, a video went viral on social media that supposedly showed someone evading police in a car by jumping the vehicle off a ramp, bouncing off the tops of of a semi-truck and a bus that were driving by, then landing on the other side of the road and driving away.
At the time of this writing, this video had been viewed more than 4.7 million times. This footage, however, does not capture a real car chase but computer generated images.
It was created by a 3D artist who uses the handle @2NCS on social media. When this video was posted to the artist's Instagram page, it was accompanied by hashtags such as #3d and #animation to indicate that this was a CGI video, not a genuine piece of footage.
@2NCS identified himself on his website as a 23-year-old named Dionisis who lives in the United Kingdom: "My name is Dionisis and I'm 23 years old. I live in UK. For me working as a car designer was a life goal. My motivation stems from the possibility that 3d graphics offer me, turning my imagination into reality. CGI is a great art that changed the way I express myself." Dinosis added that he uses the software programs Autodesk 3ds Max and Adobe After Effects to create his videos.
@2NCS has had a few other videos go viral after internet users incorrectly assumed that they were real. In 2019, for example, a video that supposedly showed a Lamborghini evading police by sliding underneath a truck racked up more than 10 million views.

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external validation processes strongly indicate that the original caption is inaccurate and out of context. The internal check, with a confidence score of 5, notes that the video depicts a car driving away from police but lacks the car bouncing off vehicle roofs as described in the caption.  This discrepancy is significantly reinforced by the external check, which achieves a perfect confidence score of 10.  The external check cites Snopes, a well-established fact-checking website, which definitively concludes that the video is computer-generated imagery (CGI) and not a real event.  Snopes's investigation provides detailed evidence supporting this conclusion, describing the video's creation and debunking the claim of a car chase involving rooftop bounces.  There is complete agreement between the internal and external assessments: the video does not show the events described in the caption.  The external validation provides stronger and more comprehensive evidence, confirming the inaccuracy and raising the overall confidence level.  The high confidence scores from both checks (5 and 10), coupled with the consistent findings, lead to a final confidence score of 10.  The lack of any evidence supporting the original caption's claim strongly suggests it is completely out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation processes concur that the caption is inaccurate and out of context.  The video shows a car evading police, but not by bouncing off other vehicles as claimed. External fact-checking confirms the video's CGI nature.
